newsitem.title: USA: Stocks retreat after Fed decision, dollar slumps.
newsitem.headline: Stocks retreat after Fed decision, dollar slumps.

text.p: Stock prices soared briefly Tuesday after the Federal Reserve decided to keep interest rates steady, but the market quickly retreated as investors assessed the implications of the central bank's move.
Bonds also jumped at first before surrendering some of their gains, but the dollar drew sustained selling pressure.
Shortly after 3:40 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 40.69 points at 5,854.06 after initially gaining 35 points on the Fed's decision.

The decision surprised some Wall Street analysts who had expected the central bank to raise rates for the first time in 1-1/2 years. Prior to the Fed's decision, the Dow index had hovered around unchanged.

"I am actually very dissapointed that the Fed didn't take a golden opportunity to nudge rates up," said Graham Tanaka, President of Tanaka Capital Management. "On a pre-emptive basis it would have been a conservative route to take."
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond was up 12/32 after initially rising nearly half a point, and its yield fell to 6.99 percent from 7.02 percent at Monday's close.
Analysts said the stock market had already priced in a quarter-point rise in interest rates. Tuesday's declines came a day after the Dow set a closing record of 5,894.74.
The Fed's decision, which had been anxiously awaited on Wall Street left the key federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans unchanged at 5-1/4 percent.
The central bank also held the discount rate, which the Fed charges banks, at 5 percent.
"The Federal Open Market Committee meeting ended at 1:40 p.m. (1740 GMT)," central bank spokesman Joseph Coyne said. "There is no further announcement."

The bland statement hid what analysts believed was one of the more contentious meetings of the policy-making committee. Anti-inflation hawks at the Fed, particularly at its regional banks, have made no secret of their desire for higher rates to cool off the economy and head off inflation.
Out of 55 economists surveyed in a Reuters poll, 31 had expected the Fed to hike rates on Tuesday. Some analysts said the Fed move was justified by a lack of inflationary pressures.

Philip Orlando, chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management said, "We believe the Fed's action to leave rates unchanged is fully justified given the complete absence of inflation and a noted deceleration in economic activity during the quarter to date."
Meanwhile, the dollar plunged, trading at 1.5020 German marks, down from 1.5125 marks on Monday. The currency fell to 109.20 Japanese yen vs. 109.89 yen.

Currency traders said the Fed's decision to hold monetary policy steady might not inflict long-term damage to the dollar because short-term interest rates were likely to head higher before the end of the year.
"To me the handwriting is on the wall," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist and senior vice president at Norwest Corp. "It's a question of when (a rate hike) comes, not if it will come."
The upbeat dollar outlook was due to a belief that the central bank remained hawkish on inflation regardless of Tuesday's decision on rates, analysts said.

"I still believe they prefer to act early on the rate side if they have to and there will be enough of them that they'll have a consensus, I would believe, before the year is out," said Michael Faust, foreign exchange manager at Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser.
